metadata.title: Visualizing Sellers of Illicit Narcotics on Soundcloud.com | by Mitchell Telatnik | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Visualizing Sellers of Illicit Narcotics on Soundcloud.com
metadata.description: Many online drug sales occur on darknet markets — platforms hidden on the dark web for the sale of illegal goods. However, sales of these goods are starting to transition from the dark web to the…

all_paragraphs: Many online drug sales occur on darknet markets — platforms hidden on the dark web for the sale of illegal goods. However, sales of these goods are starting to transition from the dark web to the surface web in places like Instagram and Snapchat.

These sellers are advertising their Instagram and Snapchat profiles across the web. One place this is happening is in the comment section of Soundcloud, a popular online music streaming site. Below is a screenshot of a comment, with identifiable information redacted, advertising marijuana, cocaine, and LSD.
Visualizing these advertisements can provide insight into how this market operates, who the major players are, and what they are selling.

In order to visualize this data, a variation of a python framework that scrapes Soundcloud comments and extracts the Snapchat and Instagram accounts from comments advertising the sale of narcotics was developed. The original framework includes two components: a web scraper and an account extractor. An article on this framework can be seen here.

In order to scrape comments from Soundcloud.com, a variation of the web scraper was developed. This scraper scrapes the Soundcloud comments for a given song and stores the user, comment text, song name, and song url in a csv file. For these visualizations, the top three songs on Soundcloud were scraped: @MEH by Playboi Carti, Find My Way by Baby Jesus, and Blueberry Faygo by Lil Mosey. A total of 17,048 comments were scraped.
Because this account extractor component only gathers the Snapchat and Instagram account names, new components for different visualizations needed to be developed in order to extract the needed data.

In order to create a word cloud using the text from comments that are advertising the sale of illicit narcotics, a new component was developed to extract the comments, turn the text of the comments into vectors, and export them to a csv that contains a list of individual words. A list of stopwords was also provided to eliminate useless words from the visualization. The stopwords used were:
In order to visualize the number of repeated comments advertising the sale of illicit narcotics, a new component was developed to extract the comments and store the comment text in a csv file.

In order to visualize the percentage of comments that were advertising the sale of illicit narcotics, a new component was developed to identify the comments that advertised the sale of illicit narcotics and label those comments with the word Yes, and other comments with the word No.

The above word cloud visualizes the top 50 words by count out of 1,977 words from comments identified as advertising the sale of illicit narcotics. The most common advertised drugs are marijuana, codeine, THC vaporizer cartridges (known as “carts”), mushrooms, Xanax, and unknown prescription drugs (“pills”). Many comments also referenced the states of Colorado and California, suggesting that drugs, most likely marijuana, are sourced from these locations, or are at least advertised as so. It also appears that many of these sellers will mail the drugs to the customer with discreet shipping.

The above chart shows comments that have been posted multiple times with the exact same comment text. The chart only includes comments that have more than 1 occurrence. Out of 57 distinct comments, only 5 were commented more than 10 times, and 17 were commented more than twice. This can help identify potential key players in the market.

Out of the 17,048 comments scraped from Soundcloud.com, 222 of them were advertising the sale of narcotics. This is 1.3% of all comments, meaning more than 1 out of every 100 comments on Soundcloud advertise the sale of drugs. While this number might seem low, it is actually quite staggering considering that comments on Soundcloud should have nothing to do with the sale of drugs.

Scraping Soundcloud.com comments to find sellers of illicit narcotics seems to be a promising area of research. These comments are rather prevalent with 1.3% of comments on the three songs scraped advertising the sale of narcotics. In addition, these comments are concentrated on a few posters and advertise discreet shipping and are generally advertising the sale of marijuana, codeine, THC vaporizer cartridges, mushrooms, Xanax, and unknown prescription drugs.
I will continue this research and post additional articles below. In addition, you can find my article on the development of this framework below.
